metadata.title: The Farm at Black Mountain College (1933-1957)
metadata.description: Detailed records of the BMC farm operations, livestock, crops, and key personnel
metadata.source: David Silver, 'The Farm at Black Mountain College' (2024), published by BMCM+AC and Atelier Editions
archives_consulted: Black Mountain College Museum + Arts Center
Center for Creative Photography, University of Arizona

farm_overview.philosophy: Self-sufficiency, communal living, experiential learning, organic farming practices

major_events.description: Helen Boyden receives Borsodi's 'Flight from the City', sparking farm discussions
After Nat builds chicken coop based on Borsodi's design, Bailey and Norm drive to Swannanoa Test Farm and buy 12 Rhode Island Red chicks - 'with permission from no one'
Nat reroofs barn and storage shed, replaces farmhouse patio and back steps
Nan and Norm live in farmhouse and manage farm over summer
Nat completes pigpen for $6 using salvaged chestnut wood
Nancie, Eurie (registered Berkshires) and Mary (unregistered) purchased from Asheville Farm School
College has 25 pigs through breeding program with B. Brown's boars
College buys Lake Eden property for $12,500 (Stephen Forbes gift) plus $1,000 from Dreier family
BMC wins two second-place ribbons: Best Work Horse (Mark) and Best Stalk Corn
Local farmer Ross Penley joins BMC, helps clear Lake Eden fields
Molly Gregory joins as woodworking instructor, becomes farm manager
Professional team and students build main barn over 7 weeks
Barn completion celebrated with community barn dance

major_events.event: Milking house and corn silos built
major_events.description: Molly designs and builds milking house; corn silos constructed with Pomona Terra Cotta tiles
Molly and students can 100 gallons beets, 85 gallons beans, 50 gallons kraut
Farm reaches peak: 35 cows, 33 pigs, 100+ chickens, 3 horses, 9 ducks, 1 goat
Three farm structures completed during summer
Jagna Braunthal runs milking operations at 5am and 5pm daily
Ross Penley leaves after behavioral issues
Conscientious objectors Ray Trayer and Cliff Moles take over farm
Moles and Trayer develop 'Getting Acquainted with Agriculture' course
After training successors and transforming farmhouse, Molly departs
Ted Dreier forced to resign from college after Board of Fellows decision, ending main farm advocacy
After conflict, Moles asks wife Shirley 'How soon can you be ready to go?' - 'By tomorrow.' They return to Shenandoah, Iowa.
Ray and Dorothy Trayer depart. Local farmer Doyle Jones hired with wife Claire (Cherokee) and 14-year-old son Ben.
Doyle Jones, 'angry and sensing the end,' packs up family and belongings including television, leaves BMC for good.
Student Terence Burns appointed interim farm manager. Thanksgiving 1954: 'Last gathering with the old convivial, self-sustaining BMC spirit.'
Last Black Mountain College farmer 'long gone.' Severe food crisis. Students forage for food. Entire beef herd goes missing.

first_pigs.notes: Nancie and Eurie were registered thoroughbreds; Mary was unregistered

breeding_partner.name: B. Brown
breeding_partner.arrangement: Pigs transported to Brown's farm twice yearly for breeding

economics.piglet_sales: Sold to local farmers at profit

dairy_cattle.source: Dreier purchased; also bought Stella Penley's cow

beef_cattle.source: Dreier purchased 5 Angus from Phoenixville, PA for $815

first_flock.source: Swannanoa Test Farm (in Oteen, run by NC Dept of Agriculture)

animals.name: Mark
animals.notes: First horse; won second place at 1937 Black Mountain Community Fair

vegetables.name: Corn
vegetables.notes: Both sweet corn and field corn

vegetables.name: Potatoes
vegetables.notes: Bumper crop sold at Asheville Farmer's Market for $225

feed_crops.name: Field corn
feed_crops.notes: For silage and animal feed; 1,200 bushel storage capacity

feed_crops.name: Barley
feed_crops.notes: Pasture and feed; increased milk production when grazed

feed_crops.name: Soybeans
feed_crops.notes: 12 acres planted; hay and soil enrichment

cover_crops.name: Crimson clover
cover_crops.notes: Clapp's favorite for regenerative qualities; 15 acres planted

cover_crops.name: Cow peas
cover_crops.notes: Soil-enhancing after heavy feeders like tomatoes

orchards.production: 1,500 bushels marketable apples in peak years

blue_ridge_period.name: Pigpen/Hoghouse
blue_ridge_period.materials: Salvaged chestnut wood rails, salvaged lumber from tumbledown structures

lake_eden_period.name: Milking house
lake_eden_period.design_source: Government pamphlet from Swannanoa Test Farm

lake_eden_period.name: Beef shed
lake_eden_period.notes: Controversial due to budget overruns; construction halted by Board of Fellows February 1944

lake_eden_period.name: Machinery shed
lake_eden_period.capacity: Equipment on one side, 1,200 bushels corn on other

lake_eden_period.name: Bullpen
lake_eden_period.reason: Built after fight between Guernsey bull King's Regent and Angus bull Black Burgess

founders_and_advocates.name: Theodore 'Ted' Dreier
founders_and_advocates.contributions: Chief fundraiser, purchased Angus cattle with personal funds ($815), advocated for farm during wartime

founders_and_advocates.name: Norm Weston
founders_and_advocates.contributions: Drove to farms for learning, established free plowing agreements, managed summer farming

founders_and_advocates.name: Anne 'Nan' Howard Chapin
founders_and_advocates.contributions: First student, summer farmer with Norm, student recruitment leader

founders_and_advocates.name: Nathaniel 'Nat' Stowers French
founders_and_advocates.contributions: Built chicken coop, pigpen, farm infrastructure; first student on Board of Fellows

farm_managers.name: Ross Penley
farm_managers.contributions: Cleared Lake Eden fields, planted cover crops, supervised dairy operations

farm_managers.name: Mary 'Molly' Gregory
farm_managers.contributions: Transformed farm operations, built milking house/henhouse/beef shed, established canning operations, produced vegetables for most of college's needs

farm_managers.name: Raymond 'Ray' Trayer
farm_managers.contributions: Implemented organic farming practices, taught first farming course 'Getting Acquainted with Agriculture', composting operations

farm_managers.name: Clifford 'Cliff' Moles
farm_managers.contributions: Farm inventory systems, organic practices, taught farming course. Left after conflict - asked wife 'How soon can you be ready?' - 'By tomorrow.'

farm_managers.name: Doyle Jones
farm_managers.contributions: Managed dairy herd, provided milk/eggs/butter. Struggled with vegetables due to limited budget. Left 'angry and sensing the end.'

farm_managers.name: Terence Burns
farm_managers.contributions: Trained by Doyle Jones. Appointed interim manager after Doyle's departure. Last person to manage farm operations.

student_farmers.name: Bailey
student_farmers.contributions: Proposed raising chickens, learned from 'poultry man' Jones

student_farmers.name: Jagna Braunthal
student_farmers.contributions: Ran morning and evening milking at 5am/5pm

student_farmers.name: Ati Gropius
student_farmers.contributions: Milk cooling, cream skimming, butter making

student_farmers.name: Ruth Asawa
student_farmers.notes: Made buttermilk especially for Josef Albers; volunteered as college barber to fund milkhouse expansion

student_farmers.name: William 'Bill' Treichler
student_farmers.role: Student farmer under Moles and Trayer

community_partners.name: S.H. Clapp
community_partners.contributions: Taught soil management, organic gardening, crop rotation, cover crops

community_partners.name: John Gary McGraw Sr
community_partners.contributions: Advised on local farming customs, plowing agreements

community_partners.name: Bernhard Laursen
community_partners.role: Farm manager, gymnastics and folk dancing teacher

community_partners.name: Bas Allen
community_partners.contributions: All-purpose college handyman, helped with farming

work_program.description: Required student labor on farm and campus

soil_management: Cover crops (crimson clover, lespedeza, cow peas)
sources_of_knowledge: S.H. Clapp at Mountain Test Farm

1933.notes: Farm idea emerges; first chickens purchased

1934.notes: First summer farming by Nan and Norm

1935.notes: Work Program and Build Program emerge

1936.notes: Pig breeding success with B. Brown

1940.notes: Decision to build Lake Eden campus

1943.notes: Peak farm operations; most self-sufficient year

1948.notes: Moles and Trayer establish organic regime

1955.notes: Last farmer gone; severe food crisis; farm collapsed
